issue.title: [ENH] Forecasting composition to infer sp param from data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The `sp` param of forecasters could be automatically infered from data e.g. by means of FFT.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Having a composition e.g. `AutoSP()` that will set `sp` param of given forecaster. Optionally we could predict multiple seasonalities as a `List[int]`. 

**Additional context**
FFT implementation, see #3406

body: Hi is this issue up for grabs? I'd love to contribute...would love to dive into any references or pointers to get started as well...thanks

up for grabs indeed!

A good starting point would be https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.fft.html which we may simply want to interface.

> up for grabs indeed!
> 
> A good starting point would be https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.fft.html which we may simply want to interface.

Thanks for the pointer...getting on it
Is this issue sorted or can I take this on? I would love to with a little guidance @fkiraly

I suppose silence for a month may mean @silvererudite is no longer working on this - are you still on this?

Either way, there are *two* potential things to implement:
* a transformer, which given a series outputs the fourier spectrum
* a parameter estimator, which estimates the seasonality parameter by a spectrum power related test

Here's the developer guide for adding a new estimator: https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/developer_guide/add_estimators.html

Hey! I am back from my holiday break. Hopefully, you are doing well @fkiraly ! I got a general idea of what I must do for this, but I need help with where to start. Can you point me to the file(s) for starting points/examples of implementation?

Of course!

* Here's the developer guide for adding a new estimator: https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/developer_guide/add_estimators.html
* A good starting point could be https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/routines.fft.html which we may simply want to interface.

Hi! @fkiraly. I have a question related to the task; fft requires evenly-spaced signal samples; should I assume the user knows this? Or should I implement something as below

1.  take user input for the frequency of sampling and the start date(can be the default), then filter out the periodic data and ignore the rest. (Also giving user warning that some data is not used), if filtered data's size<some value % of original, return an error.
2. A simple checker, if data is not filtered well by the user, then returns an error
3. implementing a non-equispaced Fourier transformer

hm, @blazingbhavneek, that's indeed an interesting question.

I would go ahead and first just interface the `numpy` method, and use the `iloc` index rather than the `loc` index. This should be said clearly in the docstring, and it will result in an evenly-spaced sequence/signal.

Discrete Fourier transforms are defined on a non-equally-spaced signal as well, typically this is generalized by taking the delta signal supported at the indices in the general form of the (non-discrete) Fourier transform, although it is less common in practice afaik.

For the latter, I would suggest:

* start with the `iloc` one first, this is a straightforward interfacing task. Get it merged, there's already enough to deal with in terms of code formatting, CI, getting PR merged, etc, which is not content but just open source, GitHub & code convention related.
* in a second step, if you like, you can add non-equally spaced DFT. My approach would actually be a little "trick" where you stick the additional phase from the unequal spacing in the complex part of the coefficients. As `numpy` can deal with complex coefficients, that should (I hope) work? I would switch via a transformer parameter, e.g., `indexing` that can be `"iloc"` or `"loc"`.
